headline: McDonald’s, Palantir, Novo Nordisk Earnings: What to Watch Next Week
summary: Earnings season marches on, with quarterly results from Berkshire Hathaway, Palantir and McDonald’s among the highlights over the next week. This past week featured results from four companies in the “Magnificent Seven,” plus President Trump’s reciprocal tariff deadline and a weak July jobs report.

headline: Business Lookahead: US company reports, trade data from China
summary: STORY: From a slew of corporate earnings to rate decisions in Britain and Mexico, these are the stories to watch in business and finance in the coming week.:: Results and refinancingA raft of bellwether blue chip companies report earnings, including Caterpillar on Tuesday, then Disney and McDonald’s on Wednesday.Also on tap are some U.S. economic data releases that could help further gauge the health of the world's largest economy.Durable goods orders are out on Monday, while the ISM services purchasing managers' index is on Tuesday.:: Slowing stimulusBeijing is trying to sort out how to pivot the world’s number two economy to one built on consumers, instead of factories.Trade data due Thursday, with inflation figures to follow, will give the latest reading on how arduous the task remains.Meanwhile, trade talks with the U.S. ended without a breakthrough, though an extension is in the works.:: Jobs and pricesThe Bank of England meets on Thursday to set interest rates amid inflation and falling employment.Analysts expect a quarter-point cut to 4%, though some think the BoE might have to call a halt to the process given the warning signals about inflation.:: Trade and ratesMexico's central bank policymakers also meet on Thursday to decide on interest rates.They’re expected to deliver another 25-basis-point cut to lower rates to 7.75% - which would be a three-year low.But Mexico's trade relationship with its northern neighbor is adding to uncertainty, even as President Claudia Sheinbaum secured a pause on new tariffs coming into effect.

raw.headline: Business Lookahead: US company reports, trade data from China
raw.summary: STORY: From a slew of corporate earnings to rate decisions in Britain and Mexico, these are the stories to watch in business and finance in the coming week.:: Results and refinancingA raft of bellwether blue chip companies report earnings, including Caterpillar on Tuesday, then Disney and McDonald’s on Wednesday.Also on tap are some U.S. economic data releases that could help further gauge the health of the world's largest economy.Durable goods orders are out on Monday, while the ISM services purchasing managers' index is on Tuesday.:: Slowing stimulusBeijing is trying to sort out how to pivot the world’s number two economy to one built on consumers, instead of factories.Trade data due Thursday, with inflation figures to follow, will give the latest reading on how arduous the task remains.Meanwhile, trade talks with the U.S. ended without a breakthrough, though an extension is in the works.:: Jobs and pricesThe Bank of England meets on Thursday to set interest rates amid inflation and falling employment.Analysts expect a quarter-point cut to 4%, though some think the BoE might have to call a halt to the process given the warning signals about inflation.:: Trade and ratesMexico's central bank policymakers also meet on Thursday to decide on interest rates.They’re expected to deliver another 25-basis-point cut to lower rates to 7.75% - which would be a three-year low.But Mexico's trade relationship with its northern neighbor is adding to uncertainty, even as President Claudia Sheinbaum secured a pause on new tariffs coming into effect.

headline: AI gains and strong earnings support Wall Street as tariff woes linger
summary: NEW YORK (Reuters) -With more than half of second quarter earnings reported and stocks near record highs, company results have reassured investors about the artificial intelligence trade that has energized Wall Street, even if tariff worries curtailed buying.  With results in from 297 of the S&P 500 companies as of Thursday, year-on-year earnings growth for the second quarter is now estimated at 9.8%, up from 5.8% estimated growth on July 1, according to LSEG data.  "The earnings season has been unambiguously better than expected," Art Hogan, chief market strategist at B. Riley Wealth in Boston, said.

"The earnings season has been unambiguously better than expected," Art Hogan, chief market strategist at B. Riley Wealth in Boston, said.

headline: CNH Industrial posts upbeat results as cost-cuts cushion slump in equipment demand
summary: Farm and construction equipment maker CNH Industrial reported second-quarter profit and revenue above Wall Street estimates on Friday, as its ongoing effort to reduce costs helped offset pressures from lower sales and production. The Basildon, UK-based company has been producing tractors and combines below retail demand to reduce excess dealer inventories, as it manages through a cyclical period of lower sales – a strategy also adopted by peers Deere, AGCO and Caterpillar. CNH expects 2025 sales to drop below last year's levels and warns that, combined with reduced production, this will likely put further pressure on its margins.

CNH expects 2025 sales to drop below last year's levels and warns that, combined with reduced production, this will likely put further pressure on its margins.
